Febrile seizure would typically be associated with fever, while benign focal epilepsy and juvenile myoclonic epilepsy have different seizure characteristics.

The symptoms described in the question, along with the EEG finding of three-per-second spike and wave discharge, point towards the diagnosis of absence seizure. It is important to note that absence seizures usually do not involve convulsions, and can often be mistaken for daydreaming or inattentiveness.

The symptoms of the patient include staring spells with frequent blinking and EEG findings of three-per-second spike and wave discharge, which are classic signs of absence seizures. Febrile seizures are usually caused by fever, and the patient had no other recent illness. Benign focal epilepsy usually presents with different symptoms such as localized movements, and Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy usually presents in older children or adolescents.

The symptoms, including the staring episodes for 30 to 60 seconds, blinking, and normal return to self afterwards along with EEG showing three-per-second spike and wave discharge, suggest the most likely diagnosis is absence seizure. Febrile seizure is seen in infants and young children with fever, while benign focal epilepsy is characterized by focal seizures that remain localized within a particular region of the brain. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy typically begins in adolescence and is characterized by myoclonic jerks.
